I.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM  
 
1.  The proposed Sustainable and Reliable Energy Access Program—Western and Central 
Java aims to (i) improve electricity reliability for households, small and medium-sized enterprises, 
and  industries to  support  Indonesia’s  continued  economic  growth  and  to  alleviate  poverty; 
(ii) strengthen institutional capacity to enhance the systems of the Perusahaan Listrik Negara 
(State Electricity Corporation) [PLN] procurement, financial management, and asset and waste 
management; and (iii) promote technological innovations and business models and a power grid 
automation system that will help enhance the sustainability of PLN’s operations (e.g., electric 
vehicle charging infrastructure, rooftop solar photovoltaic systems, and a geographic information 
system-based distribution management system). The proposed program is aligned with the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) Strategy 2030 and country partnership strategy for Indonesia, 2020–
2024,  and  is  included  in  the  country  operations  business  plan  2021–2023.1 The  program 
contributes to achieving Sustainable Development Goal 7 (affordable, reliable, sustainable, and 
modern energy for all) and the Paris Agreement on climate change. 
 
2.  The program is aligned with the following impact: the quality of life in Indonesian society 
enhanced through the provision of electricity.2 The program will have the following outcome: 
access to sustainable and reliable energy for the population in Western and Central Java 
enhanced.  The  program  has  three  outputs:  (i)  power  grid  rehabilitated,  strengthened,  and 
expanded; (ii) clean energy use promoted; and (iii) institutional capacity strengthened. The total 
expenditure of the program is estimated to be $1.411.0 billion during 2021–2025 based on the 
PLN’s Electricity Power Supply Business Plan 2021–2030. ADB loan for the proposed program 
will contribute $600 million from ordinary capital resources. The PLN and other financing partners 
will provide the balance. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  Indonesia is close to achieving its goal of universal electricity access, supporting its 
continued economic growth trajectory, low-carbon initiatives, and poverty reduction. Therefore, 
the government is prioritizing sustainable and reliable electricity supply in Java.3 Supplying 
reliable electricity to meet this demand and to support increased use of renewables requires 
strengthening Java’s power grid, which suffers from power quality issues, frequent interruptions, 
and electricity losses that impact economic growth, increase carbon dioxide emissions, and delay 
business investment. The need for grid strengthening was further demonstrated by the cascading 
power failures and massive blackouts that occurred in August 2019.4  
 
4.  The improvement of power supply reliability and quality and integration of variable clean 
energy from rooftop solar photovoltaic systems and electric vehicle charging infrastructure into 
the power system requires knowledge of a wide range of technical issues, new technologies, and 
power  grid  operation  proficiency.  In  connection  with  the  proposed  program,  the  PLN  has

2 
requested assistance from ADB to strengthen its capacity in (i) power grid system planning and 
automation; and (ii) solar photovoltaic integration to grids, electric vehicle charging services, and 
utility-scale energy storage systems. 
 
5.  The technical assistance (TA) will help strengthen the capacity of PLN staff nationwide (of 
which 23% will be women) in emerging technologies like energy storage and solar photovoltaic 
systems, which will assist in optimum integration of renewable generation into the electricity 
network. Further, the training on electric vehicle charging will assist in expanding the electric 
vehicle charging infrastructure in Indonesia to cater to the government’s planned increase in 
electric vehicle deployment. Capacity building on distribution planning and power grid automation 
will help PLN staff to improve electricity reliability and quality and reduce distribution network 
losses. 
 
6.  The TA may also facilitate selected staff of the PLN, including eligible female staff, to visit 
and/or utilize applications to and from the Republic of Korea to gain knowledge and experience 
in the practical application of emerging technologies. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
7.  Output: The capacity of the State Electricity Corporation on power grid reliability 
and  quality,  including  efficient  utilization  of  emerging  technologies  such  as  grid 
automation,  electric  vehicle  charging,  and energy  storage,  strengthened.  The  TA  will 
conduct a cluster of capacity building activities for PLN staff, units, or offices on (i) power grid 
system planning and automation; and (ii) energy storage systems, solar photovoltaic integration 
to grids, and electric vehicle charging stations. This will assist in achieving the outputs of the 
proposed RBL program. The training activity may include a visit to and from an appropriate 
research facility or utility in the Republic of Korea to gain knowledge and exposure to emerging 
technologies.5 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
8.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund and administered by ADB. TA 
funds will not be used for civil works, procurement of large-scale equipment, permanent staffing 
costs, or hiring staff consultants. The key eligible expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1.  
 
9.   The PLN will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office and 
workshop space, office supplies, secretarial assistance, local communication facilities, and other 
in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA activity does not 
commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
10.  ADB will administer the TA. The Energy Division of the Southeast Asia Department will 
select, supervise, and evaluate consultants, and organize workshops. As the executing and 
implementing agency, the PLN will support the implementation and monitoring of the capacity 
building program, including (i) developing and reviewing the selection criteria of the candidates 
and the capacity building program agreements; (ii) maintaining financial accounts and keeping

12.  Consulting services. The consultants will have extensive experience in design, operation, 
and deployment of power system planning and automation; grid codes; electric vehicle charging 
infrastructure;  distributed  energy  systems;  energy  storage  technologies;  solar  photovoltaic 
system integration; and energy regulation development. It is estimated that 22.5 person-months 
of consulting services, comprising 10.5 person-months of international consulting services and 
12.0 person-months of national consulting services, are required to undertake this work. One 
contract package for $419,000 will be used to recruit an international firm through quality- and 
cost-based selection with a simplified technical proposal. The individual national consultant will 
be recruited using individual consultant selection for a contract package of $61,000. ADB will 
engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to 
time) and its associated staff instructions and guidance notes.6 
 
13.  Cofinancier requirements. The Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership 
Fund requires semiannual monitoring and progress reports.
